pages.raw_output: <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 82, 193, 149]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 100, 767, 116]]<|/det|> UNIVERSITY OF CAMBRIDGE INTERNATIONAL EXAMINATIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 117, 680, 133]]<|/det|> International General Certificate of Secondary Education <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 171, 196, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 214, 425, 259]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 826, 107]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will measure the capacity of a drinks cup by three methods capacity of a cup is the maximum volume of liquid that it will hold in normal use.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 876, 153]]<|/det|>
You have been supplied with a cup on which the maximum level \(\mathbf{MAX}\) is marked both inside and out, as shown in Fig. 1.1. Do not fill the cup beyond this level.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[386, 163, 561, 306]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 324, 510, 344]]<|/det|>
<mark>[a]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 355, 146, 374]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 355, 242, 373]]<|/det|>
Method 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 369, 792, 392]]<|/det|>
In Method 1, the capacity \(V_{1}\) is determined from the mass of water in the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 401, 181, 420]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 401, 541, 420]]<|/det|>
Fill the cup to the marked level with water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 432, 180, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 621, 451]]<|/det|>
Place the cup, containing the water, on the balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 463, 435, 482]]<|/det|>
Read and record its mass \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 494, 875, 513]]<|/det|>
<form>m = .................................................... $g$ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 524, 180, 543]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 524, 611, 543]]<|/det|>
Leave the water in the cup for the next experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 555, 180, 574]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 555, 875, 597]]<|/det|>
Calculate a value for the capacity \(V_{1}\), using your reading from **(a)(ii)** and the equation \(V_{1} = \frac{m}{\rho}\), where \(\rho = 1.00 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 705, 875, 724]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{1} = .......................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 146, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 736, 243, 754]]<|/det|>
Method 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 750, 861, 771]]<|/det|>
In Method 2, the capacity \(V_{2}\) is measured directly from the volume of water in the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 781, 180, 800]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 781, 608, 800]]<|/det|>
Carefully tip the water into the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 812, 181, 831]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 812, 774, 831]]<|/det|>
Read and record the volume \(V_{2}\) of the water in the measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 842, 875, 863]]<|/det|>
<form>V_{2} = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 242, 90]]<|/det|>
Method 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 85, 848, 123]]<|/det|>
In Method 3, the capacity \(V_{3}\) is estimated using the average diameter of the cup considering the cup as an approximate cylinder.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 133, 567, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 348, 510, 367]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 378, 181, 397]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 378, 843, 399]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the diameter \(d_{1}\) of the top of the cup, as shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 408, 875, 429]]<|/det|>
<form>d_1 = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 440, 181, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 440, 683, 460]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the diameter \(d_{2}\) of the base of the cup.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 470, 875, 491]]<|/det|>
<form>d_2 = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 502, 178, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 502, 796, 521]]<|/det|>
Measure and record the height \(h\) from the base to the marked level **MAX**.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 533, 875, 552]]<|/det|>
<form>h = ................................................. cm

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[848, 549, 875, 567]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 580, 180, 599]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 579, 875, 598]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average diameter \(D\) using your readings from **(c)(i)** and **(c)(ii)**, and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 599, 428, 626]]<|/det|>
the equation \(D = \frac{(d_1 + d_2)}{2}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 710, 873, 728]]<|/det|>
<form>D = ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 740, 181, 759]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 740, 875, 784]]<|/det|>
Calculate an approximate value for the capacity \(V_{3}\), using your results from **(c)(iii)** and **(c)(iv)** and the equation \(V_{3} = \frac{\pi D^{2}h}{4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 866, 875, 887]]<|/det|>
<form>V_3 = ....................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 883, 875, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 819, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate methods of preventing loss of thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 876, 154]]<|/det|>
You are provided with two beakers labelled \(\mathbf{A}\) and \(\mathbf{B}\). Beaker \(\mathbf{A}\) has a layer of insulation. Do not remove this insulation. Beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) has a lid but no insulation. You are also provided with a supply of hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 164, 576, 184]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 196, 861, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 502, 509, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 534, 144, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 180, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 533, 648, 552]]<|/det|>
Pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 565, 180, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 564, 875, 613]]<|/det|>
Place the thermometer into the water. When the reading has stopped rising, measure the initial temperature of the hot water in the beaker and, at the same time, start the stopclock.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 611, 735, 630]]<|/det|>
Record this temperature at time \(t = 0\) s in the first row of Table 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 643, 180, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 642, 875, 675]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in the table, the temperature of the hot water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}\), \(60 \text{s}\), \(90 \text{s}\), \(120 \text{s}\), \(150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 689, 183, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 688, 875, 721]]<|/det|>
Remove the lid from beaker \(\mathbf{B}\) and pour approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Replace the lid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 736, 181, 754]]<|/det|>
<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 734, 561, 754]]<|/det|>
Repeat steps (a)(ii) and (a)(iii) for beaker \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 73, 181, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 756, 92]]<|/det|> Complete the column headings and enter the values of \(t\) in the table. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 103, 515, 122]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 133, 692, 368]]<|/det|>
beaker Abeaker B
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 808, 108]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the current and potential difference in an electric circuit. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 411, 138]]<|/det|> The circuit has been set up for you. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 576, 170]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 180, 824, 348]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 364, 509, 382]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 395, 144, 414]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 395, 181, 414]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 803, 415]]<|/det|> Connect the crocodile clip to the resistance wire at the position labelled A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 427, 181, 445]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 427, 284, 444]]<|/det|> Switch on. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 441, 798, 477]]<|/det|> Read and record in Table 3.1, the potential difference \(V\) and the current \(I\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 556, 92]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(V / V\) (\(y\)-axis) against \(I / \text{A}\) (\(x\)-axis).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[228, 100, 720, 448]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[846, 480, 875, 499]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 144, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 510, 180, 530]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 510, 875, 546]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(M\) of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 696, 875, 717]]<|/det|>
<form>M = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 727, 181, 746]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 727, 819, 747]]<|/det|>
The gradient \(M\) is numerically equal to the resistance \(R\) of the power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 758, 875, 794]]<|/det|>
Write down the resistance \(R\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 804, 875, 824]]<|/det|>
<form>R = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[789, 836, 875, 855]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 751, 92]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the reflection of light by a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 123]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 135, 213, 154]]<|/det|>
ray-trace sheet

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 153, 888, 780]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 797, 509, 816]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 808, 91]]<|/det|> Draw a line about \(8\mathrm{cm}\) from the bottom of your ray-trace sheet. Label this line AB <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 477, 106]]<|/det|> Mark a point \(\mathbf{N}\), near the centre of \(\mathbf{AB}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 724, 122]]<|/det|> Draw a normal to \(\mathbf{AB}\) at point \(\mathbf{N}\). Label the other end of this normal \(\mathbf{L}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 153]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 769, 153]]<|/det|> Draw a line \(\mathbf{CD}\) passing through \(\mathbf{N}\) and at an angle \(\alpha\) to \(\mathbf{AB}\) where \(\alpha = 20^{\circ}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 165, 144, 183]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 633, 183]]<|/det|> Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) some distance apart on line \(\mathbf{LN}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 435, 199]]<|/det|> Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 146, 229]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 875, 245]]<|/det|> Place the mirror on line \(\mathbf{CD}\) and view the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 4.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 875, 306]]<|/det|> Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) some distance apart so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\), and the pins \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\), all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 320, 144, 338]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 425, 338]]<|/det|> Remove the mirror and the pins. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 875, 369]]<|/det|> Repeat steps **(b)**, **(c)** and **(d)** for an angle \(\alpha = 30^{\circ}\), replacing pins \(\mathsf{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{2}\) in their original positions in step **(c)**. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 141, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 423, 400]]<|/det|> Remove the mirror and the pins. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 412, 144, 431]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 412, 767, 431]]<|/det|> Draw a line passing through the first \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) positions and reaching \(\mathbf{AB}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 444, 144, 463]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 836, 463]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 4.1, the angle \(\theta\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 139, 494]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 703, 494]]<|/det|> Repeat steps **(g)** and **(h)** for the second set of \(\mathsf{P}_{3}\) and \(\mathsf{P}_{4}\) positions. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 505, 517, 523]]<|/det|> Table 4.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 536, 636, 622]]<|/det|>
